questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been clinically proven to reduce mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF). It works by decreasing the heart rate, reducing myocardial oxygen demand, and limiting the harmful effects of sympathetic nervous system activation in heart failure. Along with metoprolol and carvedilol, bisoprolol is one of the few beta-blockers approved for use in CHF due to its demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes.

 

Remember - Drugs that decrease mortality are primarily those that inhibit the renin-angiotensin pathway, including beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers), and angiotensin receptor blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not typically used in the management of CHF due to its lack of cardioselectivity. It has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with CHF.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties. While it is useful in the management of hypertensive emergencies, it is not used for chronic management of CHF and has not been shown to decrease mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Pindolol: Pindolol is another non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). It is not suitable for CHF management and does not have evidence supporting a mortality benefit in heart failure patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following primary second messengers is involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles while focusing on near objects?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IP3

 

IP3 is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles to focus on a near object.

 

The contraction of ciliary muscles of the eye, mediated via M3 receptors, while relaxation is mediated via the B2 receptor.

 

Mg receptors act via the formation of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG), leading to an increase in intracellular Ca+ and activation of protein kinase C, respectively. The increase in intracellular Ca+ leads to contraction of the ciliary smooth muscle of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: This is incorrect because cAMP is not the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles for near vision focus. cAMP typically mediates relaxation processes.

 

Option B. cGMP: This is incorrect. cGMP is not involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles for focusing on near objects.

 

Option C. Na+ inflow through a channel: This is incorrect. Na+ inflow is not the primary mechanism for the contraction of ciliary muscles in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IP3 is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles necessary for focusing on near objects, mediated by M3 receptors.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change
Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

questions.text: Which is the Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ministry of Home Affairs

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India. The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs, with the Prime Minister serving as its chairperson. The nodal center for disaster management is at the district level.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare: While this ministry plays a role in health-related aspects of disasters, it is not the nodal ministry for overall disaster management.

 

Option C. Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change: This ministry deals with environmental aspects but is not responsible for coordinating disaster management activities.

 

Option D. Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment: This ministry focuses on social welfare programs but does not coordinate disaster management activities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs serves as the nodal ministry for disaster management in India, with the district being the nodal center for implementation. NDMA functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs with the Prime Minister as its chairperson.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures. On examination, blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

This case presents a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy, as indicated by the symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, along with severely elevated blood pressure (220/110 mmHg). In hypertensive emergencies, the goal is to rapidly reduce blood pressure using intravenous medications to prevent further organ damage.

 

IV Labetalol is a preferred treatment in hypertensive emergencies, especially those involving encephalopathy. Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker that can reduce blood pressure quickly and effectively, making it ideal for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Nifedipine: Oral nifedipine is not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies because it does not act rapidly enough, and oral medications are generally avoided in such acute settings.

 

Option B. Oral Nicardipine capsules: Like oral nifedipine, oral nicardipine is not suitable for emergencies due to its slower onset of action. Nicardipine is more effective in its intravenous form for such cases.

 

Option C. IV Nitroglycerine: Although IV nitroglycerine can be used in hypertensive emergencies, it is not the best choice for hypertensive encephalopathy. Nitroglycerine is more commonly used in cases involving acute coronary syndromes or pulmonary edema, but it is usually avoided in patients with CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for Hypertensive emergencies:

 

  • Encephalopathy - Nicardipine or IV Labetalol

  • Intracranial Hemorrhage - Nicardipine or Labetalol

  • Acute Coronary Syndrome – IV Nitroglycerin

  • Pulmonary Edema - Intravenous Nitroglycerin / Sodium Nitroprusside

  • Aortic Dissection – Nicardipine in combination with Esmolol or Labetalol

  • In Pregnancy - Labetalol

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U*V/P, where U is?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine urea in mg /100ml

 

'U' in the urea clearance stands for urine concentration of urea in mg /100ml.

 

The formula for renal clearance of a substance is,

 

Clearance (C = U × V / P),

 

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance in mg / ml
  • V = Urine flow rate in ml/min
  • P = Plasma concentration of substance in mg /ml.

 

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orange curve

 

In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production.

 

 

Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and disappears by 6 months of age. Postpartum which is the pattern represented by the orange curve.

 

The type of hemoglobin variant is determined by the combination of globin chains.

Adult hemoglobin consists of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. ﻿

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green Curve: Incorrect. The green curve represents beta-globin chain production, which increases after birth and replaces gamma-globin chains in adult hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Black Curve: Incorrect. The black curve does not accurately represent any specific globin chain production in this context.

 

Option C. Blue Curve: Incorrect. The blue curve represents epsilon-globin chain production, which occurs during the embryonic stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orange curve in the provided image represents the production of gamma-globin chains, which are crucial during the fetal period and decline after birth as beta-globin production increases.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident (RTA) presents with fracture of hand with hypothenar atrophy. Nerve involved in him is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • In the hand, the ulnar nerve gives motor innervation to the hypothenar (palmaris brevis, abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi) and the thenar (adductor pollicis, deep head of flexor pollicis brevis) muscles. 
  • Also, it supplies the palmar and dorsal interossei and medial 2 lumbricals.
  • The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist, resulting in motor and sensory loss.
  • Mechanisms of injury include trauma like motor vehicle accident; nerve impingement; lacerations at the wrist; and Guyon’s canal cyst.
  • A motor vehicle accident resulting in a fracture of the metacarpal or phalanges can lead to injury of the ulnar nerve.
  • This is indicated by the atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, leading to flattening of the hypothenar eminence. 
  • Other clinical features of ulnar nerve injury include:
    • Loss of hypothenar eminence
    • Loss of adduction of thumb
    • Loss of abduction of fingers
    • Clawing of 4th and 5th digits

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Injury to this nerve would typically result in wrist drop due to loss of extensor muscle function, not hypothenar atrophy. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles in the upper arm. Its involvement would affect arm flexion and not the hypothenar muscles.

 

Option D. Median nerve: The median nerve supplies the thenar eminence and the first two lumbricals. Injury to this nerve would result in issues with thumb opposition and grip, but not hypothenar atrophy.

 

Additional Information: 

 

  • Flexor pollicis brevis superficial head is supplied by median nerve and deep head is supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The first and second lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • The third and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • When the lumbricals are paralyzed, they can result in a deformity known as a "claw hand."
  • Ulnar or median nerve injury can lead to a deformity known as "claw hand."
  • Among these, ulnar nerve palsy is more commonly associated with claw hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text:
What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction.
  2. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria.
  3. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Only 3

 

The accurate fact concerning skeletal muscle is that the release of calcium occurs from the sarcoplasmic reticulum only.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Extracellular calcium plays a significant role in sustaining cardiac muscle contraction , not in skeletal muscle.

 

2. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is filled with high concentrations of calcium ions stored in its vesicular tubules. Upon the occurrence of an action potential in the neighboring T tubule, these calcium ions are discharged from each vesicle.

 

4. Activation of  voltage-gated calcium channel is essential in excitation-contraction coupling, i.e. it a has important role. Activation of receptor results in the initiation of calcium release from RyR channels, leading to the liberation of calcium ions from the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, consequently triggering muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Purkinje cells are specialized neurons located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Golgi cells: These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

 

Option D. Granule cells:

 

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have a large, flask-shaped soma from which extend many branching dendrites. The dendritic tree is oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the cerebellum, extending into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass into the white matter and are the only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex to synapse with cells in the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text:
Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body?(INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Eye

2. Testes

3. Kidney

4. Gut

5. Lungs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,2,3,4,5 are correct

 

The countercurrent mechanism is present in various parts of the body where the inflow and outflow run parallel and in opposite directions, facilitating efficient exchange processes:

 

  1. Eye: The theory of counter-current mechanisms predicts that there is diffusion of oxygen from retinal arterioles into adjacent retinal venules. A possible counter-current exchange was investigated by measuring hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SatO2) in first-order retinal arterioles and venules at different distances from the optic disc.
  2. Testes: The temperature is regulated to be low for spermatogenesis by heat exchange between spermatic arteries and veins in a countercurrent manner.
  3. Kidney: The urine is concentrated using countercurrent exchangers, particularly in the loop of Henle and the vasa recta.
  4. Gut: Certain parts of the gut use countercurrent mechanisms to optimize nutrient absorption.
  5. Lungs: Countercurrent mechanisms in the lungs help in efficient gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The countercurrent mechanism is a biological system found in various organs such as the eye, testes, kidney, gut, and lungs, allowing for efficient exchange and regulation processes.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

 

Nernst equation: EMF (millivolts) = [61/Z] X log [Co / C]

 

  • EMF = electromotive force (Nernst potential)
  • z = charge of ion
  • Co = concentration outside
  • C = concentration inside

 

When using this formula, it is usually assumed that the potential in the extracellular fluid outside the membrane remains at zero potential, and the Nernst potential is the potential inside the membrane.

 

The sign of the potential is negative (-) if a negative ion is diffusing from outside to inside.

Therefore, Nernst potential = 61/-1 * log [100/10] =-61 * log [10] = - 61 mV

 

To get the charge, always check the final charge intracellularly.

 

The potential is negative intracellularly, so the Nernst equation comes out to be -61mV inside the membrane and the closest option is -60 mV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The equilibrium potential for an ion can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about behavior change stages and choose the correct answer :(INICET NOV 2023)

 

  • Statement 1: Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking.
  • Statement 2: Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walk considering its benefits to health.
  • Statement 3: Maintenance phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then.
  • Statement 4: Action phase – A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs in his family.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

The behavior change model, often based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM), outlines various stages individuals go through when changing a behavior as given below.

 

 

Statement 1: Correct. Contemplation involves thinking about quitting a behavior, such as smoking, which fits the scenario described.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The maintenance phase describes someone who has successfully sustained a behavior change, such as quitting smoking, over a long period.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Precontemplation is the stage where a person is not yet considering a change. In this case, considering starting a morning walk suggests the contemplation stage instead.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. This statement reflects a precontemplation attitude where the person is not considering change, attributed to a belief that obesity is inevitable due to family history, rather than being in the action phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct definitions of stages of behavior change is crucial in accurately assessing an individual's readiness to modify behaviors , based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM).

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1

 

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that primarily acts as a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist. By antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to diuresis or increased urine output. Adenosine normally promotes water reabsorption in the renal tubules, and its blockade by theophylline results in increased urine production. This mechanism is separate from its therapeutic action in COPD, which involves bronchodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-10: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It is not a direct target of theophylline. IL-10 plays a role in regulating immune responses, but it is not involved in the diuretic effect or the primary action of theophylline in COPD treatment.

 

Option B. Histone Deacetylase: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is an enzyme involved in chromatin remodelling and gene expression regulation. While theophylline has been suggested to have some modulatory effects on HDAC, especially in the context of COPD and asthma, it is not the mechanism responsible for the increased urine output observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Beta 2 Adrenergic Receptors: While theophylline has mild bronchodilatory effects thought to be mediated through inhibition of phosphodiesterase (increasing cAMP levels in smooth muscle), leading to relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, beta 2 adrenergic receptors are more specifically targeted by drugs like salbutamol. Theophylline's diuretic effect is not mediated through beta 2 adrenergic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.
